addressleaf.section:
Copie of my l
re
to my L. T
re
r

page.lettertext:
fol.81r
May it please your good L. Upon hope every day, to
receave
e aunswear of
e
States
to her
Ma
ties
demaundes,
I have refrained from writing, somwhat longer, then I
was willing, albeyt I had no mater since I sent you my
last,
at might in my opinion deserve the advertising,
and the lesse a great deale, because I have not yet
receaved any l
re
from your L. whose direction I attend
to some pointes of importance. The aunswear of
e
States is both fully concluded and sette downe in writing,
but not exhibited yet unto me. For knowing, as I thincke,
w
at
the tenure will be, That they are not yet in State
to satisfie her Ma
tie
I have dealt to such effect, w
t
some
of
e chiefest of them, as I am done to witte upon it,
at
they bethinke themselves further, w
at
special offer they
may make, that would be gratefull to her Hig
es
where
of I heare by secret meanes, that they will make an
ouverture unto me within fower or fyve dayes: so
at
I trust with my nexte both to send their answear unto
her, and to signifie
at withall w
ch
they shall deter-
mine for
her
better contentation.
Coronel Stuart
is very earnest in requiring his dispatche, w
ch
yet as
farre as I perceave, they doe purposely delay, till they
heare w
at
I will say, upon my l
res
out of
England:
w
ch
I thincke are kept backe by this esterly wynde,
w
ch
hath continued heere w
th
us for these 5 weekes
togither. He is also very diligent in preferring
e suite of the
Earle of Orkney
, to
e
La. Emilia
sister
to
Co. Maurice
. But
e Count hath referred him to
the generall states, and the Assemblie of
e States to
the Lady her self, who hath aunsweared flattly, that
she will not dwell so farre from her brother Co. Maurice,
and the rest of her kin
d
red. Sins
e
death of
Ernestus,
there have bin l
res
addressed from
e
Assemblie of
e States, but in very secret sorte to
e
Marquis of Haverey, and to such of Nobilitie in
e
Enemies contrey, as were co
m
only reputed to be most
discontented with the gouvernment of
e Spaniard,
to insinuat unto them, that if they were desirous to
caste of
at yoke of their Spanish servitude,
ei had
fol.81v
the fattest opportunitie,
at could be expected, and they
might make good account of
e uttermost assistance
at those of this union could in any kinde affourde.
They retourned this aunswear by a messenger
of purpose, That they would willingly joyne with
us, if so be they might obtayne the graunt of the
pointes, Of their accustomed religion, of a peace
in
France,
and of any course of proceeding, for
bannishing
e Spaniard, whether the same were di-
rectly or indirectly procured. It were replyed by
e States, by
e self same messenger, That for maters
of religion they had never no intention, to [bereave]
anie Province of
e libertie of conscience that for
France they made no doubt of inducing the King to
accord a good peace: and
at lastly they could lyke
to have
e Spaniard chased home by [all] the meanes
they could devise. The Marquis upon it
w
t
e rest of
at syde, sent a couple to Co. Maurice
who repaired unto him about eight dayes agoe
in
e towne of
Middlebourg,
e one was Mons
r
Lisfvelt, who hath bin heeretofore a chancellor
in
Brabant;
and
e other was Mons
r
Man[.]
who hath in tymes past bin an Huissier in
e chan-
cerie. In the deliverie of their message, it was
apparant to Co. Maurice,
at
e Marquis had
acquainted
de Fuentes
w
th
this practise in as
much as when they spake of expelling
e Spaniard
they proposed how to doe it, w
t
content of
e King
of Spaine and by the meanes of de Fuentes
beyng perceaved by
e Count, he bidde them pre-
sently depart. And this he hath tould me
himself, beyng very desirous
at it should not
be published, least a mater well meant, but
perhaps misreported by passing many mouths
might turne to their rebuke, by whome it was con-
trived. Though
e Duke of [Pastrovia]
be arrived at
Brussels,
it is supposed notwith
tanding
at he hath brought no Co
m
ission or
commaunde in
e Contrey. For it is written
fol.19r
from Brussels, that when he came to de Fuentes,
e upper hand beyng offered to him, he would
not accept it.
Having no other mater
to signifie p
nt
ly, I take my humble leave.
13 A
p
